facts.text: Criminal Appeal No. 40 of 1964 in the Supreme Court.

anchor.surface_text: Criminal Appeal No. 40 of 1964.

facts.text: Appeal by special leave from judgment and order dated April 24, 1963 of Madras High Court.

anchor.surface_text: Appeal by special leave from the judgment and order dated April 24, 1963, of the Madras High Court

facts.text: Madras High Court Criminal Appeal No. 22 of 1961.

anchor.surface_text: the Madras High Court in Criminal Appeal No. 22 of 1961.

facts.text: Appellant convicted by magistrate under s. 18(a)(ii) read with s. 27 of Drugs Act, 1940.

anchor.surface_text: The appellant was companyvicted by a learned magistrate under s. 18  a   ii  read with s. 27 of the Drugs Act, 1940

facts.text: Conviction for manufacturing for sale and exhibiting for sale drug OKSAL.

anchor.surface_text: for having manufactured for sale and also exhibited for sale a drug known as OKSAL

facts.text: OKSAL did not contain ingredients in proportion mentioned on label on container.

anchor.surface_text: which did number companytain the ingredients in the proportion mentioned in the label pasted on the companytainer of the drug.

facts.text: Magistrate sentenced appellant to fine of Rs. 125, in default rigorous imprisonment for one month.

anchor.surface_text: The magistrate sentenced him to pay a fine of Rs. 125 and in default of payment of the fine, to rigorous imprisonment for one month.

facts.text: Appellant appealed to Sessions Judge, conviction set aside and acquitted.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the appellant to the Sessions Judge, that companyviction was set aside and the appellant was acquitted.

facts.text: State appealed to Madras High Court, Sessions Judge judgment set aside, magistrate conviction and sentence restored.

anchor.surface_text: On appeal by the State to the High Court of Madras, the judgment of the learned Sessions Judge was set aside and the companyviction and sentence passed by the learned magistrate were restored.

facts.text: Present appeal to Supreme Court by special leave.

anchor.surface_text: Hence the present appeal by special leave.

facts.text: Prosecution produced Government Analyst certificate that drug misbranded under s.18(a)(ii).

anchor.surface_text: The prosecution produced in evidence of the charge that the drug was misbranded within the meaning of s. 18  a   ii , that is, its label bore a statement which was false as being at variance with the companyponents of the drug, a certificate

facts.text: Label stated drug contained Benzoic acid, Salicylic acid, Zinc Oxide and Boric acid in specified proportions.

anchor.surface_text: The label stated that the drug companytained Benzoic acid, Salicylic acid, Zinc Oxide and Boric acid in the proportions specified.

facts.text: Analyst report showed deficiencies: Benzoic Acid 15.5%, Salicylic acid 25%, Zinc Oxide 25%, Boric acid 46.3%.

anchor.surface_text: The report of the Analyst showed that the drug did number companytain these substances in the proportion indicated but were deficient as follows Benzoic Acid by 15.5 per cent, Salicylic acid by 25 per cent, Zinc Oxide by 25 per cent and Boric acid by 46.3 per cent.

facts.text: Appellant produced no evidence contrary to Analyst report.

anchor.surface_text: Sub-section  3  of s. 25 of the Act states that the report of the public Analyst shall be evidence of the facts stated therein and such evidence shall be companyclusive unless the accused person adduced evidence to the companytrary in the manner laid down in it. The appellant produced numbersuch evidence.

facts.text: Appellant contended report not in prescribed form, hence inadmissible.

anchor.surface_text: The companytention of the appellant is that the report was number in such form and hence was number admissible in evidence.

facts.text: Sessions Judge accepted appellant's contention on report form.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention was accepted by the Sessions Judge but rejected by the other two companyrts below.

facts.text: Magistrate and High Court rejected appellant's contention on report.

anchor.surface_text: This companytention was accepted by the Sessions Judge but rejected by the other two companyrts below.

facts.text: Rule 46 requires Government Analyst to supply report in triplicate in Form 13 with full protocols of tests applied.

anchor.surface_text: Rule 46 of the rules made under the Act provides that the Government Analyst shall after the test or analysis has been companypleted forth with supply to the Inspector a report in triplicate in Form 13 of the result of the test or analysis together with full protocols of the tests applied.

facts.text: Form 13 Head 7: Results of test or analysis with protocols of tests applied.

anchor.surface_text: Head 7 of Form 13 is in these words Results of test or analysis with protocols of tests applied.

facts.text: Drugs Inspector obtained samples from appellant's shop and forwarded to Government Analyst with letter for test or analysis.

anchor.surface_text: It appears that the Drugs Inspector who obtained the samples from the appellants shop duly forwarded a part of these to the Government Analyst with a letter stating that they were sent for test or analysis.

facts.text: Analyst report did not state protocols of any test.

anchor.surface_text: Now, the report of the Analyst did number state the protocols of any test.

facts.text: No dispute on components constituting the drug, only on quantities.

anchor.surface_text: Indeed numberdispute exists as to the companyponents companystituting the drug, the only dispute being as to the quantities in which they were so companytained.

facts.text: Supreme Court held report in prescribed form and admissible.

anchor.surface_text: That being so, in our view, the report is in the prescribed form and is fully admissible in evidence.

facts.text: Analyst performed analysis, not test.

anchor.surface_text: But what the Analyst did was only to make an analysis. It did number give the result of any test. Nor does it say that any test had been carried out.

issues.text: The only question is whether this report was admissible in evidence to prove that the contents of the drug were so at variance with the statement on the label and therefore the drug had been misbranded.

anchor.surface_text: The only question is whether this report was admissible in evidence to prove that the companytends of the drug were so at variance with the statement on the label and therefore the drug had been misbranded.

issues.text: The question then is, do r. 46 and Form 13 require that in the present case the protocols of tests had to be stated?

anchor.surface_text: The contention is that in the absence of the protocols the report was number in the prescribed form and was hence number admissible in evidence. It appears that protocols of test means the details of the process of test. The question then is, do r. 46 and Form 13 require that in the present case the protocols of tests had to be stated ?

arguments.claim: Rule 46 and Form 13 contemplate test and analysis as different; protocols only for test not analysis

anchor.surface_text: Obviously, the rule and the form contemplate analysis and test as two different things, for otherwise both words would number have been mentioned, number the word or been put between them. It is true that the rule and the form require that the protocols of a test should be stated. They do number require any protocols to be stated in the report of an analysis.

anchor.surface_text: Even if he should have and did number, that would number prevent the report of the result of the analysis from being admitted in evidence. That report would nonetheless be conclusive evidence under s. 25 3 of the Act.

arguments.claim: Report without protocols of test not in prescribed form per Rai Kishan v. State of Uttar Pradesh

anchor.surface_text: Our attention was drawn to the case of Rai Kishan v. The State of Uttar Pradesh. There it was observed that when a report did number state the protocols of the test applied, it could number be said to be a report in the prescribed form.

holdings.text: the report is in the prescribed form and is fully admissible in evidence

anchor.surface_text: That being so, in our view, the report is in the prescribed form and is fully admissible in evidence.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Report stated results of analysis only; Rule 46 and Form 13 distinguish 'test or analysis' and require protocols only for tests, not pure analysis; no protocols needed here as no test performed.

holdings.text: do r. 46 and Form 13 require that in the present case the protocols of tests had to be stated ? We do not think they do

anchor.surface_text: The question then is, do r. 46 and Form 13 require that in the present case the protocols of tests had to be stated ? We do not think they do.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Rule 46 and Form 13 use 'test or analysis' indicating distinction; protocols mandated only for tests, inapplicable to analysis of quantities where components undisputed.

holdings.text: the rule and the form contemplate analysis and test as two different things... They do not require any protocols to be stated in the report of an analysis

anchor.surface_text: Obviously, the rule and the form contemplate analysis and test as two different things, for otherwise both words would not have been mentioned, not the word or been put between them. It is true that the rule and the form require that the protocols of a test should be stated. They do not require any protocols to be stated in the report of an analysis.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Textual reading shows 'test or analysis' as disjunctive; protocols specific to 'tests applied'; analysis of proportions needs no test protocols.

holdings.text: Even if he should have and did not, that would not prevent the report of the result of the analysis from being admitted in evidence. That report would nonetheless be conclusive evidence under s. 25(3) of the Act

anchor.surface_text: Even if he should have and did not, that would not prevent the report of the result of the analysis from being admitted in evidence. That report would nonetheless be conclusive evidence under s. 25(3) of the Act.

holdings.reasoning_summary: s.25(3) makes report conclusive if in prescribed form and no rebuttal; failure to test does not vitiate analysis report's admissibility or evidentiary value.

anchor.surface_text: Obviously, the rule and the form contemplate analysis and test as two different things, for otherwise both words would not have been mentioned, not the word or been put between them. It is true that the rule and the form require that the protocols of a test should be stated. They do not require any protocols to be stated in the report of an analysis.

That being so, in our view, the report is in the prescribed form and is fully admissible in evidence. The Inspector in his letter to the Analyst numberdoubt stated that the sample was sent to him for test or analysis. But what the Analyst did was only to make an analysis. It is irrelevant to companysider whether he should also have carried out a test. Even if he should have and did number, that would number prevent the report of the result of the analysis from being admitted in evidence.
